Well, I mean, like I said, I was born here, so this is all I know. I've been other places, and not one of those places that's made me feel like I wanted to live there. I actually enjoy living here. In terms of where I fit, I think right now I'm comfortable. I own my home and I'm a landlord. I'm a mom; I'm raising two boys. One is already off on his own and was able to obtain housing, and the other one's in school, trying to learn. If I had anything to say about my place in Boston, it'd probably be to try and find some kind of way to make people see that the education here is not fair. If we didn't have the charter schools and some of the private institutions that offer financial assistance, our kids would not get educated the way they should in order to succeed. The fact that we have people that are privileged trying to dictate the entrance exam to Latin Academy, so that people like my child or your child could not get in or have a fair shot at it, is disheartening. And the other poor sad fact is that we have one vocational school. Do you realize that the trades are making tons of money? People with skills of plumbers and electricians, that's the job to have. And our children don't have a fair shot at it, because Madison, the vocational school, is not what it should be. It's too hard [inaudible] to get into the union. So the fate of Boston in terms of our children is a little scary to me.

So a lot of them... And that's the other thing. Right now, I'm also very disheartened that the candidate of my choice wasn't selected. Oh, same. Sorry. I'm sorry. But the two that are there, to me don't represent me. It's a lot of talk right now, because they want the job, but they still don't represent me. So they're pandering to coming into the neighborhoods now for photo ops. But my sister's a neighborhood association president now. And even to just get one of them to come I'm in there, she sent a representative. She never showed up. So I hear all this, "Oh, we do the work. We're on the ground." It's nonsense. At least in terms of what I know from experience. I want to know truly. I mean, I think the best chance we have right now is... And I don't even know if that, because in one case you have Michelle Wu, who to me seems like the better candidate, but she's the same person who wants to dig in my pockets as a landlord and tell me she wants to enact rent control. That's not going to work for me. I didn't work hard to get my own to try and get a better way for my kids for somebody else to dictate it. So I don't care how fair she thinks it is. It's not inclusive of people in my position. And there are quite a few in Boston who are just making middle class, and now are going to be burdened with that whole scenario. You have the other one, Essaibi George, the fact that she's struggling in terms of her husband and the properties and her not even being able to file her taxes, and even [inaudible]. Also, it almost feels to me like she's being put there to save the people who don't want any change. They just want somebody in there who'll keep the status quo and won't disrupt the vote. Whereas the person I wanted to vote, she was strongly going to upset the vote. And I feel that it's now going to be business as normal again, where-

And I believed her. And she talked the talk. She had a plan. She verbalized that plan. I'm not hearing that. I hear a bunch of regurgitation from these other two, so it's a little hard for me to try to figure out who of the two... It's almost like with Trump and Hillary. I didn't want either one of them, but you have to pick somebody. You don't want vote to go to waste, but at the same time, is it going to benefit you? It's not, probably not.

I need a better education for my child. And I want it to be fair for people who may not have the advantages that I have or the networking that I have, because there's tons of people that don't know where to turn. And they feel like they have to have their kids stuck in these schools that are awful, God awful.

All right. This is Annette. I do agree with what the young lady said. And my take on it is I've been a resident of Boston all my life also. And I haven't been anywhere else. I have been a voter since I turned 18. I am now 63. Okay? Where do I find myself in Boston? I don't even see myself in Boston. I'm trying to hold on in Boston, but eventually I'm going to be forced out. Right now, I'm going through a separation. So I lived in a house with me and my husband and my mother-in-law, who owned the house. But when she passed, in her will, she said, "Sell the house." Because I'm going through a struggle right now, there's no help. I mean, I can't see myself paying. And I don't want to pay. And I have a good job, but I [inaudible] my job for a long time. And I work for the state. And I don't want to be pushed out of Boston. And I certainly don't want to be paying all these people's high, high rent, their mortgage. I don't want to pay their mortgage. And they said, "Oh, we got these homebuyer classes out here." But I took three homebuyer classes, and I have a good credit score, but I still can't get a home in Boston. I mean, I can go to Brockton. I can go to Randolph. I can go all those places. But for some reason, the strings are being pulled in these homeowner classes for whom they want to be pulled. If you don't know anybody, you ain't getting nothing. Okay? And I am so sick and tired of hearing, "Low income, low income, low income." What do I have to do? Go out here, have three kids, to be able to get something, to get some help? You know what I'm saying? I have to go out here and don't take another promotion, because you make too much. I couldn't even get temporary housing when I'm going through my divorce. I couldn't get no shelter, because, "You made too much." So I had to stay with my friends and my family and continue to stay. There's nothing out here for the middle working class. Everything is you have to have a Mass Health card, which I don't have. My son happened to go to O'Bryant, but he's in Maryland. So that makes me a one single person. So for a single person out here, they don't act like we have any struggles. You know what I'm saying? They want you to pay this $3,000 rent and gas utilities. And I had a person that was supposed to be helping me telling me, "Well, you need to get away from your life insurance." My life insurance? Oh, shit. You must not have life insurance, because I'm not dropping my life insurance." You know what I'm saying? It's nothing out here for the middle class. If God forbid, if you're single and you're going for a divorce or whatever, it's nothing out here. There's single people, I have come across, living in their cars. Thank God they don't have to be at the Mass Ave thing. But it's like you're giving people who want to be out here more than you're giving people who are working. There's a lot of working class people that are suffering too. And the only option is if you want anything, you have to leave the city. You know what I'm saying?

I think all these politicians... I mean, I voted for Kim too. Now I have to vote for somebody. It would have to be Wu, because I'm not going with the other girl, because I don't even think she can relate to African American people. And I think she's going to play the old game, the old White-boy game. They're just putting her in the front, because she don't really know anything, and she supports one of the unions. She's going to go back to old-boy White-boy game. I agree. I agree with you. She's a figurehead being put in place to keep the status quo. She's going to get in there, and they're going to dictate to her what she want and how they want her to do it, and she's going to do it. Because my thing is, you got the Chinatown for the Chinese people. You had... Who else had their place? The north end for the Italians. South Boston got their place for their Caucasian White boys syndrome thing, South Boston. You know what I'm saying? George has to have the Mecca, but we really, really didn't have anything that we can build up and call our own, because every time something happened, they were pushing us out. When they took away Proposition 2 1/2, they strategized that. They knew we were going to be here today. They wanted us here today, because they took away housing, Proposition 2 1/2. That some people had housing and the landlords can only charge a certain amount. Now the landlords are charging 3,000, 4,000. You have all these places. And the Seaport, they can't even rent all these luxury apartments. So now they're trying to get middle class to take those apartments. But those are too much. You still have to have money to live and pay your car insurance, your life insurance. You got people moving into these apartments and moving out. I just stay Boston. Boston knew what they were doing. Mayor after mayor passing the baton to the next mayor, to the next mayor, to the next. They all knew what they were doing. They get their paychecks, and it's all about them. It's not about the people. It's not about the people. It's true. It's about [crosstalk]- Look at the face of the Seaport. There are barely any Black businesses there. And that's a beautiful space, but you don't see our kind there. You look at all the new malls- Nothing is for us. If they really want to do something, they need to make a section of Boston, give it to our people, and let us build that place up. Okay- Let us build for us by us. But they won't want that to happen, because they done gave Boston to the wealthy. They done gave Boston- Not to mention that would be less dollars going to the neighborhoods that they wanted to go to, and therefore negates their whole purpose of being. They have given Boston away. Most of all my friends and family that grew up in the South End back in the day, they're all every place, Randolph, Brockton, Stoughton. It's nobody really here anymore. And that's what they do. I have friend whose grandmother lived in the South End in one of those beautiful brownstone. It wasn't very well kept. She didn't have the money, and they knew it. They knocked on her door every day for a year and finally convinced her to sell it.

I think all these politicians... I mean, I voted for Kim too. Now I have to vote for somebody. It would have to be Wu, because I'm not going with the other girl, because I don't even think she can relate to African American people. And I think she's going to play the old game, the old White-boy game. They're just putting her in the front, because she don't really know anything, and she supports one of the unions. She's going to go back to old-boy White-boy game. I agree.

Well, they started that in the '80s. In the '80s, they started doing that, because our seniors didn't understand, and they were older and the children had gone elsewhere. And they started that. But that was all in the Proposition 2 1/2 for the South End. They got the South End, and they strategized to move up. You know what I'm saying? And my thing is, I'm not in a low income bracket. I do not have the children. I mean, I commend you for having a house in Boston or Dorchester, where you have it and staying focused and sitting down with your peers and letting them know as you go on, "This is what needs to be done," because that plants you here. But those of us who don't have our own home and were forced to move out and then take that commute. I don't want to take that commute. I'm used to getting on the bus and going to work. So what they do is they uplift and move the African American people, because you don't see China people going through this. People in China, their seeds are planted. They're going to take care of them. They [crosstalk]-

So that's my take. My take is these politicians, they get in there, and they do the same old thing. It is nothing new under the sun. What's the name of those projects right there by Whittier Street, where the Boston police headquarters is? That used to be all Black people next to Madison Park Village. They literally gave all those people Section 8 certificates, moved them out, and now it's going to be considered lower south end for middle and upper class people. Barely a few- Yeah, absolutely right. Yeah. You're absolutely right. You're absolutely right. They moved my girlfriend out of her, what is it, Madison Park apartment and put her over there in JP, some high tower. But you know what? I don't care how much we say we want Boston to change. It's not going to change. It's not going to change. And if our people get together and try to do whatever, it's not. These folks got Boston locked down and money- So- ... Boston is about money. They're money hungry. Okay. And I'm sorry for [crosstalk] but I think- Okay, Cecilia, you're next. Go ahead, Cecilia.

My question is what are you going to do for the middle class? Because I'm sick and tired of hearing what we going to do for the low-income people. What are you going to do for the middle class? Because a lot of the low class don't even come out and vote. What are you going to do for the middle class, people who voting for you and we still get nothing? Mm-hmm (affirmative). True.

I would like to see our new politicians coming into office explore, just as the other two women just explained, that we're constantly overlooked. Our streets are a mess. Our schools are not... They're not where we expect them to be today. And I'm really struggling too also with the COVID, the vaccine mandates. Everything's changing. I mean, I understand this is our new way of life, but it is really, really hard to get used to. I just don't know that a new face coming into office is going to make a huge difference. Like the woman just said, the politicians come in, and it's the same old thing, time just repeating itself over and over and over again. And I've sat on a lot of committee meetings, Boston city council meetings, and I realize now most of the money is going back into the state. We pay the tax dollars, and the money gets circulated throughout the state. They budget for policing overtime, I think, was, what, 30 million or something like that the past two years. They have a new women's prison coming up, and they're planning to spend $50 million on that one. You don't have any money going into [crosstalk]- Speaking of, do you know that there's a new proposal on this particular ballot that's going to change the way that the mayor budgets and to give the city council more leeway into managing that budget? So therefore, if you have a city council person on there for your district, they can allocate to get more of that money in your city. Did an anybody know that that was part of the ballot? Yes, [crosstalk], yes. See, they keep telling us that all the time. They're saying, "Fill out the census. This is for services in your community. We want to see where the services are most needed." And we don't see anything coming in. We don't see any new community centers being built. We don't see any roller skating rinks. We don't see any tracks for the kids to ride those motorbikes that they're riding all over the damn city. And

My question is, "What are we going to do?" Show me what difference looks like in their eyes. Show me how you are going to address all the concerns throughout every district. Show me how you pay these city workers to come out and work on the streets, and they leave the streets clumpy. Show me how you have these teachers coming into the schools, and they do more competing with the children back and forth then they do teaching. True.

And then that's a reflection on the kids that want to be there and learn. Well, the kids that are disciplined and able to sit through an entire period and get the education they need, but they suffer, because instead of you putting that kid out of class, now you're going back and forth with this child. And then I could go on and on. The police, they're paid too much money overtime to come in and police our neighborhood. And mismanaged- And I need transparency from those police. ... mistreat- They seem to think they can do whatever they want. No. Yeah, I that's what I'm saying. They mistreat our youth. They mistreat everything. We're just a mess right now. I can just say that Boston... I love Massachusetts, because I love... Well, New England. Let me say New England, because I love that you get to enjoy the four seasons here. The schools are pretty good. The opportunities to get to the schools are slim. I mean, my question is, what does difference look like to me or to you? I need to understand that my vote is going to count for something other than you taking that next step in your career.

And can I just say this? When they get these new officers, I think they should put more officers who live in the neighborhood and back into the neighborhood. Stop sending them out to [inaudible] and all these other places, and then sending us these Caucasian officers. And then they're treating our kids the way... They arresting them right off the hand. I think they should have a lot of the people in the community stay in the community. They do have a program where if you live in the city of Boston, you get some sort of preferential, but there's not a lot of people in the city that want to be police officers. But even with teachers, they say that with teachers, but they have to enforce it. They have to enforce it. You know? Yeah. Because I know teachers who live way out somewhere, and they drive back to Boston to be the teachers. And then, as far as John D. O'Bryant and Latin, those are the only two schools that our kids of color had to go to. Now you want to change it [crosstalk]- Not anymore. Right, but they want to change it, because the kids that are coming in, the Caucasian kids, they want them at those two prestigious schools. So it's like just bump our kids out and put the White folks in, the Caucasians.

But one thing about it, one person don't do anything. And even with this question on the ballot, a lot of people don't understand that question. So if you have these people coming in that don't understand the question, they're not going to even fill out the question. So again, that goes back to Proposition 2 1/2. They didn't understand the question, and guess what? This is what happened. So if somebody's not out there educating these people on this question, or they're educating a few, then a few's not going to make it. Right. A few's just not going to make it. Yeah. [inaudible] What I was going to say... My people lack. The people lack, because of not having the education they need. My people perished for not having a lack of the information. So as long as the information is going to a few people, the people are going to perish. And that's what's going on.

I think all three of us are on the same page in terms of wants. All three of us are probably on the same page in terms of working hard and basically just touching the cusp of middle class. I do believe that we're all of the understanding that it's just pandering at this point, that there's really no benefit for any of us in terms of real change. And the only thing that gives me a glimmer of hope is that Michelle Wu is connected to Ayanna, and I'm sure Ayanna will hold her to certain capacities.

I think all three of us are on the same page in terms of wants. All three of us are probably on the same page in terms of working hard and basically just touching the cusp of middle class. I do believe that we're all of the understanding that it's just pandering at this point, that there's really no benefit for any of us in terms of real change. And the only thing that gives me a glimmer of hope is that Michelle Wu is connected to Ayanna, and I'm sure Ayanna will hold her to certain capacities.

I think all three of us are on the same page in terms of wants. All three of us are probably on the same page in terms of working hard and basically just touching the cusp of middle class. I do believe that we're all of the understanding that it's just pandering at this point, that there's really no benefit for any of us in terms of real change. And the only thing that gives me a glimmer of hope is that Michelle Wu is connected to Ayanna, and I'm sure Ayanna will hold her to certain capacities.

They made an entire community over where the Boston Herald used to be, and it's full to capacity. They allow dogs. They have dog groomers. So that's not for us. So now you have the Cote Ford place over on Cummins Highway. There used to be an old Lincoln or Cadillac dealership. Going to be high-rises or townhouses. Who's moving in them? How are you getting selected? There needs to be some process that's fair to the people that have been here. So in my case, yes, it's not fair, because I own my place. But I have siblings and nieces that are really struggling to get housing. They've utilized the metro housing list and have gotten picked or selected to get into these units. But those rates, they go up at the drop of a dime. You constantly have to re-certify your paperwork. And at the end of the day, you don't own it. So what are they doing to transfer more ownership to people? I know I hear that Janey raised the deposit for first time home buyers to $40,000. But how do you get it?

I had a Section 8. I had a Section 8. But because I could not find an apartment within their three months, they took my Section 8. So again, they had a system, and that happened to quite a few people, to get them Section 8 from them people. And thank God, I already had a job. I mean, I had a good job, but Section 8 was only paying $200 of my rent. So because I was moving- 200? Right, because I took advantage, got a job, and moved up. So they were only paying 200. So when I couldn't find an apartment, because I had to move, she said, "You got three months." They gave me another three months, but there was no apartments out here at the time. And they took it. You get two extensions. They took it. And then they came around. [crosstalk]. And they came around. Listen to what they did. Then they came around a year later and said, "Rent is going up, so we're going to give people a little bit more." But at that time it wasn't about that. So I'm just sick of the game. Now I'm sick of the game, and I don't want to be on any government thing anyway, because they dictate your life.

Before it was [crosstalk] pushed out, Brockton's not even affordable anymore. Brockton's not even a great place to live, let's be clear. But the three-families that you used to be able to get for 300,000, there now are 600,000. The three-families you used to get here for 500,000 are a million dollars now. So who's going to secure a million dollar mortgage and be comfortable sleeping at night, knowing that they're paying somebody a million dollars? I don't know that person.

Before it was [crosstalk] pushed out, Brockton's not even affordable anymore. Brockton's not even a great place to live, let's be clear. But the three-families that you used to be able to get for 300,000, there now are 600,000. The three-families you used to get here for 500,000 are a million dollars now. So who's going to secure a million dollar mortgage and be comfortable sleeping at night, knowing that they're paying somebody a million dollars? I don't know that person.

It's too many games. It's too many games, but you know what? Black folks have always been survivors. That's the bottom line. Because you know what? They going to get all these high-rises, put everybody out, and God is going to say, "You know what? Now let's play." They saw the COVID, but they keep doing people the way they doing, they got to answer to God. And that's the bottom line. I don't have nothing else to say. They can play their games all they want.

It's too many games. It's too many games, but you know what? Black folks have always been survivors. That's the bottom line. Because you know what? They going to get all these high-rises, put everybody out, and God is going to say, "You know what? Now let's play." They saw the COVID, but they keep doing people the way they doing, they got to answer to God. And that's the bottom line. I don't have nothing else to say. They can play their games all they want.

It's too many games. It's too many games, but you know what? Black folks have always been survivors. That's the bottom line. Because you know what? They going to get all these high-rises, put everybody out, and God is going to say, "You know what? Now let's play." They saw the COVID, but they keep doing people the way they doing, they got to answer to God. And that's the bottom line. I don't have nothing else to say. They can play their games all they want.

I find that here, all they do is train our kids how to take a MCAS; they're not teaching them. And that's not fair to them when they go up against these kids who are actually being taught, and therefore they lose out on the seats, like the Boston Latin and the Boston academies. If we don't get something in gear... We don't have buildings that are adequate. They don't even have air conditioning. You've got mice in the stairwell. Kids are getting moldy lunches. And yet and still, you tell me there's a budget for school lunch, but then you're serving the kids salami. What are you doing with the money realistically? Because I know all of the money that's in budget is not being dwarfed by a sandwich of cold salami. Someone really needs to think about why everybody's pushing their kids to charter school, because no one wants their kid in a Boston public education, because it's not there. So that's key, because you can't have the next level working force of these educated kids, if they're not educated. And then you wonder why they're hanging on the corners, because a lot of times the parents get discouraged. They can't keep track of the kids. The kids feel burdened, because they see their moms struggling. And then they go and resort to things, so that they can try and help. And then they end up being profiled, and then they end up being in a system. And then you end up with all the things that are happening every day on the news. And then they look at us like we're savages, and we don't know what we're doing. But a lot of times you have kids raising kids. If you've got young kids, and then they don't have that matriarch to give them the education, to give them the knowledge that they need and the support and structure. So if the services were there, if the housing was out of the way, and they weren't worried about the landlord kicking them out or raising their rent or whatever the case, or family members having to stay with them, because they've been kicked out, we'd have less struggle there. And therefore, they could concentrate on other things and give the kids the attention, be at the parent teacher meetings, like they should be, and be involved, and be a voice in the community like they should. So if we had had a seat at the table, if we were offered more of these seats on these boards, where the decisions were being made... Decisions are being made without even considering us, and we're just supposed to take the after effects. And that becomes stifling, you know? Mm-hmm (affirmative).

I find that here, all they do is train our kids how to take a MCAS; they're not teaching them. And that's not fair to them when they go up against these kids who are actually being taught, and therefore they lose out on the seats, like the Boston Latin and the Boston academies. If we don't get something in gear... We don't have buildings that are adequate. They don't even have air conditioning. You've got mice in the stairwell. Kids are getting moldy lunches. And yet and still, you tell me there's a budget for school lunch, but then you're serving the kids salami. What are you doing with the money realistically? Because I know all of the money that's in budget is not being dwarfed by a sandwich of cold salami. Someone really needs to think about why everybody's pushing their kids to charter school, because no one wants their kid in a Boston public education, because it's not there. So that's key, because you can't have the next level working force of these educated kids, if they're not educated. And then you wonder why they're hanging on the corners, because a lot of times the parents get discouraged. They can't keep track of the kids. The kids feel burdened, because they see their moms struggling. And then they go and resort to things, so that they can try and help. And then they end up being profiled, and then they end up being in a system. And then you end up with all the things that are happening every day on the news. And then they look at us like we're savages, and we don't know what we're doing. But a lot of times you have kids raising kids. If you've got young kids, and then they don't have that matriarch to give them the education, to give them the knowledge that they need and the support and structure. So if the services were there, if the housing was out of the way, and they weren't worried about the landlord kicking them out or raising their rent or whatever the case, or family members having to stay with them, because they've been kicked out, we'd have less struggle there. And therefore, they could concentrate on other things and give the kids the attention, be at the parent teacher meetings, like they should be, and be involved, and be a voice in the community like they should. So if we had had a seat at the table, if we were offered more of these seats on these boards, where the decisions were being made... Decisions are being made without even considering us, and we're just supposed to take the after effects. And that becomes stifling, you know? Mm-hmm (affirmative).

And then I have people who call me all the time. They move these people to Norwell, and they send them to Norton. And they get out there, and they have to deal with these uneducated, nasty White folks that's treating them bad. And then they try to go and complain and get help, and everybody turn the other cheek. It's like, "We don't want you out here anyway." [crosstalk] funding where you can come out. Can I just tell you how emboldened they are since Trump? Since Trump, what used to be quiet, subtle racism is now in-your-face, we-don't-care-if-you-film-us racism.

therefore the services are definitely not coming our way, because they're saying we're underrepresented, so therefore no dollars are coming to you. We can't win. So how does that fair for the people who are filling it out, who are here, who are needing the help of the government? I mean, goddammit, I pay taxes and they sucked me dry on the taxes. Where's my money? I don't have any programs. And yeah, I may have a house, but shit, my kid needs stuff. Like I said, if you don't have the connections or the know-all to get your kids in these programs, to get them these jobs... Because kids want their own side money. I don't have money to be paying for no $180 Jordan sneakers. They want to be able to work. Now, the city of Boston has done a better job with the summer program this year. I noticed they had an abundance of jobs, and people were being advised to come down, "We'll get your kid a job on the spot." But if you don't know that, how would you know?

But my thing is I have grandchildren now. And when I take my grandchildren out, I like for them to be able to relax and be able to socialize with us. They all scattered into White schools. They have their White drama. But when I bring them into the city of Boston, and we go swimming at the Y, and we do things in the Y, they're able to just let their guard down and be children, not having to worry about the scrutinize of these people that they go to school. There's always a problem in schools, and the get-them and [inaudible]. And it's crazy, but when I bring them home on the weekends, and they able to just relax and go in the pool and meet up with their friends of color, that's important. It's okay to socialize with the Indians and socialize with the Asians and socialize with the White folks. But when you go somewhere, sometimes you want to let... I go swimming at the Y, and I can just feel their eyes on me, "How she going to put all those braids into that swim cap?" You know what I'm saying? I want to go to a gym for us, by us. And if I want to take my hair down, then I can take my hair down without them looking at everything I'm doing. But we don't have a place to call our own in the Boston area, because we're being pushed out. We're being pushed out. We're being pushed out.

Right. They should have got together and one should have dropped down and said, "Listen, I'm going to pull back. And if you get in, I'll bring you in. It doesn't matter." But no, it will always split in the votes, and we got to get sicker and tired of that. Somebody got to be the bigger person and say, "You know what? I'm going to push you into front [crosstalk]."

The same thing with Biden. He promised us the stars, the moons, and the sky. Oh, and as soon as he got in here, he snatched all the money from the HBCUs and they're starving. Why? Because we're taking all of our money and bringing billions of dollars over to house Afghanistanians and give them jobs and housing. In the meantime, my tax dollars can't get what they're supposed to get me as an American. Exactly. They going to get to housing. They going to get the housing. They going to get the food stamps. They going to get everything. They're already getting it. They're already [crosstalk]- They've already got the [crosstalk]. Right. So then again, for the working people, we got to step back. [crosstalk]

You're being run by the top 10 elite most rich people in the world. They're controlling the strings, and they want to keep that control. They see so many people, especially Black people, who didn't have anything, came from nothing, came from slavery, all of a sudden were able to amass a little bit of something. We're able to educate our kids. We're able to get in professions that we were always pushed out of. And now they're like, "Oh, wait a minute. They're growing. And guess what? They're now intermingling with other races and becoming a bigger... We are the minority now. We don't want to be the minority. We have to keep control. And so how do we keep control? The money. Control the money. Control the stock market. Control how all of that happens." They can hide and move their money and have laws to do and shelter theirs, but now they want regulate our little [crosstalk].

For every $83,000 that a Caucasian has, a Black person has $7 compared to it. It's ridiculous. So that just tells you that we're stuck with payday loans, or we don't have good jobs that are paying us. We don't have the cumulative wealth, because when you have your home and your property, the equity is how most people get up. Most people who lived in Southie had a house, sold the house. They moved to Braintree. But they've got the equity to move on, you know what I mean, or to make an impact, pay their kids' tuition, to put them in those good schools. It's just sad that it's a repeat of the same thing over and over for us.

[crosstalk] Ruckus and the fact that it's very difficult to have accessibility and be accepted at the same time in the area. I see a lot of diversity within the city and within the Roxbury Dorchester Mattapan area, but just because you see a lot of diverse areas doesn't mean there's affordability. I think without change, Boston will fold. The people with money will live here, but the people without money will suffer and they will continue to suffer. It's only going to get worse before it gets better. That's just my take on it and because of where I'm at and what I stand for and what I've become, I watch it all the time. That's my take on it.

Yeah. I felt, Monalisa, when you were talking about having an eight-year-old and this is all that she knows, not wanting to get out of here. This is your place and I feel that. I feel you, Kimberly, about getting denied. We've been denied a lot, trying to get my friend's house because they don't have rent... Specifically because I don't have rental history, it took us months and months and months. Then I also helped a friend who was coming home from a 30-year bid get an apartment. Luckily, we finally found somebody in the neighborhood who had family who was incarcerated and was willing to take somebody in because they know that that doesn't mean you're a bad person. So yeah, I guess I'm relating that experience of supporting my two friends this past summer to find housing but they got denied time after time. Sometimes people would just not even give them a denial, just stop talking to them once they found out they didn't have a rental history or they had a record so I feel both those things really deeply.

She's public about this so I feel fine sharing. She came home from prison about two years ago and she noticed all the housing barriers, people coming home with records, and so she started this organization that has a couple bills before the legislature trying to decriminalize... Well, oh, sorry, not... I guess decriminalize homelessness as well as make it illegal to discriminate against people because of their conviction history. There's another bill that is about making sure that when they do the set asides for affordable housing and developments, that part of that is set aside for people with records as well because people are often cut out of the public housing.

Well, oh, sorry, not... I guess decriminalize homelessness as well as make it illegal to discriminate against people because of their conviction history. There's another bill that is about making sure that when they do the set asides for affordable housing and developments, that part of that is set aside for people with records as well because people are often cut out of the public housing.
